courseDescription:
This free Online course on Global Marketing Management begins with why global marketing is imperative and how globalization of market leads to convergence and divergence. Global business comprises of a large and growing portion of the world’s total business. Today, global events and competition affect almost all companies both large and small because most sell output to secure supplies from foreign countries.

Many companies also compete against products and services that come from abroad. Thus most managers regardless of industry or company size need to approach their operating strategies from a global perspective. In view of the above this course provides a fresh up-to-date analysis of the global business environment and successfully blends a comprehensive review of global business with exhaustive discussion of what happens in the many parts of the global market.

The course not only describes the ideas of global marketing but also presents many contemporary examples, scenarios and cases. This course will therefore provide first hand knowledge of Global Marketing operations and help practitioners and budding scholars of international business. 

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this diploma course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this diploma course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison diploma is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital diploma: a downloadable diploma in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked diploma, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked diploma in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All diploma are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison diploma, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison diploma, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our diploma pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module you will learn about globalization. We will also discuss global economic environment, regional trading arrangements and multinational corporation.
topics: The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT)

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module Global Marketing Management. Foreign exchange is the monetary mechanism allowing the transfer of funds from one nation to another. Learn about buyer behavior and consumer needs which are largely driven by cultural norms.

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module you will learn the political and legal systems are vital parts of a country’s business environment. Learn about the development of competitive strategy, market size assessment and new market information technologies.
topics: International Laws, Agreements and Local Legal Environment

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module you will learn the effect of information technology on global competition, the regionalization of global marketing strategy and how to go about doing competitive analysis, and the importance of timing of entry in a particular country and the exit strategies.
topics: Effect of Information Technology on Global Competition
The Interface of R&D Operations and Marketing
Timing of Entry and Exit Strategies

modules.name: Module
modules.description: You must score 80% or more to pass this assessment

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Global Pricing : Marketing Products and Services
modules.description: In this module you will learn about global pricing, multinational diffusion and how to develop new products for global markets. Learn about global branding strategies and how to manage global product lines.
topics: Global Pricing : Marketing Products and Services - Learning Outcomes
Global Pricing : Marketing Products and Services - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module you will learn how advertising gets affected by culture and various kind of creative strategies also how to coordinate international advertising. Learn about market entry options in sales force strategy.
topics: Communicating with the World Consumer - Learning Outcomes
Choosing and Coordinating and Advertising Agency
Market Entry Options in Sales Force Strategy
Communicating with the World Consumer - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module you will learn about free trade zones, International distribution channels and retailing. Learn also steps in processing an export order and how to organize for exporting.
topics: Export and Import Management - Learning Outcomes
Government Role in Promoting Exports and Mechanics of Importing
Planning, Organization and Control of Global Marketing Operations
Export and Import Management - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module you will learn about how to go about organizing for global brand management and the life cycle of organizational structure. Learn also how to offer the right product mix is a major requirement to thrive in the emerging market.
topics: Emerging Markets and the Internet - Learning Outcomes
Global Brand Management and Organizational Structure
Product Policy, Pricing & Communication Strategy and Distribution Challenge
Global Marketing and the Internet Part 1
Global Marketing and the Internet Part 2
Emerging Markets and the Internet - Lesson Summary

slides:
• Learning Outcomes
  • Upon successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Explain the benefits, advantages and disadvantages of globalization.
    • Identify the various theories related to international trade and multinational enterprises.
    • Discuss an overview of the world economy and the various economic systems in the world.
    • Recognize the general agreement on tariffs and trade called GATT and the World Trade Organization.
    • Describe the regional trading arrangements and multinational corporation.
  • Introduction to Global Market

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Economic Arrangements & Multinational Corporations

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary
    • Companies from Western Europe, the United States, and Japan collectively produce more than three times as much in foreign markets as they export.
    • About a third of their exports and imports are transacted on an intra-firm basis between their parent companies and their affiliated companies abroad or between the affiliated companies themselves.
    • Globalization has two facets; globalization of markets and globalization of production. Globalization of market means globalization of demand and globalization of production means globalization of supply.
    • Globalization of Markets refers to the merging of historically distinct and separate national markets into one huge global marketplace.
    • The Globalization of Production refers to the sourcing of goods and services from locations around the globe to take advantage of national differences in the cost and quality of factors of production.
    • The term global marketing refers to a strategy to achieve one or more of the major categories of potential globalization benefits which include; cost  reduction, enhances customer preference etc.
    • According to the theory of absolute advantage by Adam Smith's The Wealth of Nations, A country’s wealth is based on its availability of goods and services. Each country should specialize in those products that give it a competitive advantage, leading to: Specialization. Greater efficiency and Higher global output.
    • Growth in international financial flows (which include foreign direct investment, portfolio investment, and trading in currencies) has achieved a life of its own.
  • Lesson Summary

    • The term global marketing refers to a strategy to achieve one or more of the major categories of potential globalization benefits which include; cost  reduction, enhances customer preference etc.

    • Growth in international financial flows (which include foreign direct investment, portfolio investment, and trading in currencies) has achieved a life of its own.
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Discuss the historical role of US dollar and the development of today's international monetary system.
    • Explain the balance of payments.
    • Identify how to go about marketing in the euro-zone, European Union or euro area.
    • Discuss culture and the various elements that make up culture.
    • Describe the global accounts management.
    • Discuss the political environment of the different countries in which a company operates.
  • Historical Role of US Dollar and Development of Today's International Monetary System

  • Lesson Summary
    • Foreign exchange is the monetary mechanism allowing the transfer of funds from one nation to another.
    • The existing international monetary system always affects companies as well as individuals whenever they buy or sell products and services traded across national borders.
    • The adoption of the euro as a common currency in the European Union in 1999 has challenged the supremacy of the dollar as a global currency.
    • Financial crises in Latin America and the U.S. have reverberated throughout the world as a global recession.
    • The gold standard is a monetary standard that pegs currencies to gold and guarantees convertibility to gold.
    • In the study of international trade, the principal source of information is the balance-of-payments statement of the trading nations.
    • Balance of payment is a double entry system, similar to that used in accounting.
    • Monetary and fiscal policy must take the BoP into account at the national level.
    • Buyer behavior and consumer needs are largely driven by cultural norms.
    • Cultural backgrounds also influence consumers' information processing and buying motivations.
    • Companies that recognize cultural norms that their competitors have so far ignored often gain a competitive edge.
  • Lesson Summary

  • Upon successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Discuss the international agreements and international laws and local legal environment.
    • Describe the development of competitive strategy.
    • Explain market size assessment and the new market information technologies.
    • Identify the reasons for international marketing segmentation.
    • Recognize and discuss the global, foreign and local cultural, consumer cultural positioning strategies.

  • Lesson Summary
    • The political and legal systems are vital parts of a country’s business environment, and in navigating different markets, firms must understand how and where national business environments converge and diverge.
    • International politics has always been characterized by the predominance of strong ideological links, centered around, and dominated by a relatively small number of large powers. Domestic politics cannot be isolated from international politics.
    • Given the complexity of the global marketplace, solid marketing research is critical for a host of global marketing decisions.
    • Most of the cultural blunders in global marketing stem from inadequate marketing research.
    • Marketing research is the systematic design, colleaion, analysis, and reporting of data and findings relevant to a specific marketing situation facing the company.
    • In most developed countries, a fairly accurate estimate of the market size for any particular product is easily obtainable.
    • Global marketing research projects have to cater to the needs of various interest groups: global and regional headquarters, local subsidiaries.
    • Variation in customer needs is the primary motive for market segmentation.Most companies will identify and target the most attractive market segments that they can effectively serve.
  • Lesson Summary

    • Variation in customer needs is the primary motive for market segmentation.Most companies will identify and target the most attractive market segments that they can effectively serve.
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Discuss the effect of information technology on global competition.
    • Discuss the regionalization of global marketing strategy and how to go about doing competitive analysis.
    • Identify target market selections and the various modes of entry like exporting, licensing and franchising.
    • Explain the importance of timing of entry in a particular country and the exit strategies.
    • Distinguish between standardization versus customization.

  • Lesson Summary
    • The financial, trading and industrial activities across national boundaries have rendered these political boundaries increasingly irrelevant.
    • Firm is a collection of activities that are performed to design, procure material, produce, market, deliver and support its product. This set of interrelated corporate activities is called as the value chain.
    • The availability and explosion of information technology such as telecommunication, electronic commerce has forever changed the nature of global competition.
    • Standardization is one part of a global marketing strategy and it may or may not be used by a company, depending on the mix of the product-market conditions, stage of market development, and the inclinations of the multinational firm's management.
    • Making the "right" entry decisions heavily impacts the company's performance in global markets.
    • Entry decisions will heavily influence the firm’s other marketing-mix decisions.
    • Joint venture is the most common form of entry. It is any form of association or partnership which implies collaboration for more than a transitory period.
    • Cooperative joint venture is an agreement for the partners to collaborate but does not involve any kind of equity investments.
    • Products are arguably the most crucial element of a company's marketing program. Product decisions are integral to the company's value proposition.
  • Lesson Summary
